posts.title: La Casa del Deán in Puebla
posts.excerpt: What remains of the Casa del Deán is an outstanding example of renaissance architecture and murals made in the viceroyalty of New Spain.

posts.title: Puebla de los Ángeles and the classical architectural tradition

posts.title: John James Audubon, The Wild Turkey
posts.excerpt: This life-size painting of a wild turkey is a copy of the first page in Audubon's famous book Birds of America.

posts.title: Art in American Colonies and the United States, c. 1700–1865
Thomas Crawford, George Washington Equestrian Monument

posts.title: Codex Canadensis
posts.excerpt: This manuscript contains about 180 illustrations of people, plants, and animals in New France (a French colony in North America)—including a unicorn.

posts.title: Brummett Echohawk, An Island of Redbuds on the Cimarron
posts.excerpt: Light and color take center stage in this soul illustration of the Oklohoma landscape where Echohawk and his family have lived for generations.

posts.title: Paukeigope (Kiowa), Cradleboard
posts.excerpt: Meant to carry a baby and created by a community of women, this cradleboard is an expression of love.

posts.title: Jasper Francis Cropsey, Mount Jefferson, Pinkham Notch, White Mountains

posts.title: Paquimé jars

posts.title: Frederic Church, The Natural Bridge, Virginia

posts.title: Attributed to Basilio Santa Cruz Pumacallao, The Virgin of Bethlehem
posts.excerpt: Commissioned by the Bishop, the painted Virgin conveys the power of evangelization in the Viceroyalty of Peru.

posts.title: Robert Mills and Lieutenant Colonel Thomas Lincoln Casey, Washington Monument

posts.title: The Virgin of Pomata: images of Andean faith
posts.excerpt: Combining Indigenous and European conventions, the Virgin of Pomata was one of the most popular images in the colonial Andes.

posts.title: Víctor Patricio Landaluze, Three Kings Day in Havana

posts.title: A colonial Andean portrait of Fermín Francisco de Ustaríz

posts.title: Louis Sullivan, Carson, Pirie, Scott Building
posts.excerpt: Sullivan believed that “form must ever follow function” and designed this department store with that adage in mind.

posts.title: Painting the 1650 Cuzco earthquake
posts.excerpt: The destructive earthquake of 1650 is remembered in this colonial-era painting of Cuzco.

posts.title: Taíno Kuisa
posts.excerpt: The carved kuisa are used in a spiritually significant Taíno ceremony to access the world beyond.

posts.title: James Abbott McNeill Whistler, Symphony in White, No. 1: The White Girl
posts.excerpt: Forgoing the tradition of narrative painting, Whistler aspired to create a beautiful "symphony."

posts.title: 1877–1898 in the United States, an introduction
1848–77 in the United States, an introduction
1800–48 in the United States, an introduction
Ferdinand Deppe, The Mission of San Gabriel, Alta California in May 1832
posts.excerpt: Deppe's San Gabriel Mission portrays an imagined mission landscape—one still very much tied to a European colonial project.

posts.title: Diego Antonio de Landaeta, Portrait of Petronila Méndez

posts.title: Vicente Albán, Quito series

posts.title: Carlos Julião, "Black Kings and Queens"

posts.excerpt: Painted by Ataíde and his workshop, the Church of Saint Anthony, Santa Bárbara is filled with whimsical rococo ornament.

posts.title: Testerian Catechism, The Egerton Codex

posts.title: Corn pith sculptures
posts.excerpt: The cristos de caña are emblematic of emerging Indigenous Christianity.

posts.title: Virgin of Chiquinquirá

posts.title:
Códice Maya de México
Getty Conversations
posts.excerpt: The Códice Maya de México is a remarkable testament to the complexity of Maya astronomy.

posts.title: The Missouri Compromise and the dangerous precedent of appeasement

posts.title: The problem of picturing slavery

posts.title: Hearst Chalice

posts.title: Taíno duho

posts.title: Juan Pedro López, Our Lady of Guidance

posts.title: A Wari tunic

posts.title: Africans in Guaman Poma’s Nueva Corónica

posts.title: The colonial Andes and the Viceroyalty of Peru

posts.title: Portrait of Don Marcos Chiguan Topa

posts.excerpt: Oller inspires a sense of monumentality in his paintings of common fruits from Puerto Rico.

posts.title: Poverty Point, Louisiana

posts.title: Olmec Colossal Heads

posts.title: The Chief Johnson Totem Pole

posts.title: Asher B. Durand, Kindred Spirits

posts.title: Frances Jones (Bannerman), In the Conservatory

posts.title: Inka checkerboard tunics

posts.title: Burnham and Root, The Monadnock Building

posts.title: “A Cheap Farm House,” c. 1864–onward

posts.title: Winslow Homer, Taking Sunflower to Teacher

posts.title: Official Portrait of Bishop Luis Francisco Romero
posts.excerpt: Never underestimate the power of a well-chosen accessory!

posts.title: Crown of the Virgin of the Immaculate Conception, known also as the Crown of the Andes

posts.title: The story of the Oyster Man, a Tlingit totem pole

posts.title: Haida potlatch pole

posts.title: Solomon Nunes Carvalho, View of a Cheyenne Village

posts.excerpt: At the Alamo, the representation of patriotic heroism and brave sacrifice eclipses Spain’s earlier colonial presence and the history of the site’s ruination, reconstruction, and reframing.

posts.excerpt: It took Carrie Bethel 3 years to make this basket

posts.excerpt: These receptacles held liquid offerings, the surface of the liquid were eyes that saw into the underworld.

posts.title: Double-headed serpent
posts.excerpt: Snakes shedding their skin was a powerful metaphor for the Aztecs and is reflected in their pantheon of gods.

posts.title: Clovis culture
posts.excerpt: The first clear evidence of human activity in North America are spearheads used to hunt large game.

posts.title: Ancient Colombian goldmaking
posts.excerpt: For centuries Europeans were dazzled by the idea of a lost city of gold in South America… but did it really exist?

posts.title: More on the Aztecs (Mexica)
posts.excerpt: During the twelfth century C.E. the Aztec (or Mexica*) were a small and obscure tribe searching for a new homeland.

posts.title: Olmec stone mask
posts.excerpt: Dress for the job you want, not the one you have: could this mask pendant turn its wearer into a god?

posts.title: Olmec figurine
posts.excerpt: Olmec figurines are known for their baby faces, as well as a mixture of feline and human traits.

posts.title: Baltasar de Echave Ibía, The Hermits
posts.excerpt: A continuous narrative, this shows three different parts of the story, each in a different part of the landscape.

posts.title: New Spain, an introduction
posts.excerpt: The Spanish reused the stones of pagan temples to build their new capital atop the Aztec city, Tenochtitlan.

posts.title: Tlaloc vessel
posts.excerpt: This vessel represents the goggle-eyed deity associated with rain and crops, critical for the agricultural Aztecs.

posts.title: Independence from Spanish rule in South America
posts.excerpt: Enlightenment ideals of democracy planted the seeds for colonial movements in the Spanish colonies of the Americas.

posts.title: Biombo with the Conquest of Tenochtitlan and View of Mexico City
posts.excerpt: This screen offers an idealized bird’s eye view of Mexico City on one side, and depicts the Conquest on the other.

posts.title: Chakalte’, Relief with Enthroned Ruler
posts.excerpt: Look up! This elaborate carving could be seen as one walked into the temple, but only VIPs had access.

posts.title: Mirror-Bearer
posts.excerpt: This fabulously-dressed mirror-bearer imitates the humans who performed this function in the royal courts.

posts.title: Vessel with a mythological scene
posts.excerpt: During ceremonies, the user of this cup might be invited to share the story depicted here in Maya glyphs.

posts.title: Introduction to the Spanish Viceroyalties in the Americas
posts.excerpt: Both Europe and the Americas were forever changed by Columbus’ accidental landing in the Caribbean in 1492.

posts.title: Juana Basilia Sitmelelene, Presentation Basket (Chumash)
posts.excerpt: The artist used Spanish coins as models for the coats of arms woven into this basket in California, then New Spain.

posts.title: Nasca Geoglyphs
posts.excerpt: These images carved into the desert floor cannot be truly appreciated from the ground—so who were they made for?

posts.title: Feline-Head Bottle
posts.excerpt: Multiple points of view are combined in the decoration of this vessel, tip it and see!

posts.title: Offering #4, La Venta
posts.excerpt: These seventeen baby-faced figures may have represented a priestly ritual, a sacrifice, or a procession.

posts.title: Yaxchilán—Lintels 24 and 25 from Structure 23 and structures 33 and 40
posts.excerpt: Over a hundred lintel relief sculptures depicting scenes from royal life survive from Yaxchilán.

posts.title: Latin American art: an introduction
posts.excerpt: “Latin America” is an imperfect but useful term for a vast and culturally diverse area.

posts.title: Painted Vessel (Enthroned Maya Lord and Attendants)
posts.excerpt: Over a thousand years before Instagram, Maya painted vases communicated about the lives of the rich and famous.

posts.title: Featherworks: The Mass of St. Gregory
posts.excerpt: This remarkable object takes its subject from European prints, but was made by an Indigenous artist.

posts.title: William Sidney Mount, Bargaining for a Horse
posts.excerpt: Is there a political message behind this image of two farmers settling the price of a horse?

posts.title: Richard Caton Woodville, War News from Mexico
posts.excerpt: Painted for a divided US, people from North and South could identify with this image—others remain marginalized.

posts.title: Camelid sacrum in the shape of a canine
posts.excerpt: Though some debated that this was made by humans, scholars are now confident some of its markings were hand-carved.

posts.title: John Trumbull, The Declaration of Independence
posts.excerpt: Trumbull traveled up and down the Eastern Seaboard to paint the members of the Continental Congress from life.

posts.title: Francis Guy, Winter Scene in Brooklyn
posts.excerpt: This snowy image of a bygone Brooklyn is sprinkled with farm animals, townspeople... and casual racism.

posts.title: Inka ushnus: landscape, site and symbol in the Andes
posts.excerpt: The Inkas filled the landscape with symbols of their presence, including these platforms.

posts.title: Olmec mask
posts.excerpt: This face has a naturalistic quality to its skin, but its mouth gives us pause—what does it mean?

posts.title: Winslow Homer, Northeaster
posts.excerpt: The artist eliminated a key element of this innovative painting five years after he finished it.

posts.title: Charles Willson Peale, Staircase Group (Portrait of Raphaelle Peale and Titian Ramsay Peale I)
posts.excerpt: Peale’s sons beckon us up the stairs, but be careful—it might hurt!

posts.title: Winslow Homer, The Fog Warning (or Halibut Fishing)
posts.excerpt: Homer’s fisherman just wants to bring his halibut safely to his ship—but as usual, nature is ruining everything.

posts.title: Mission Church, San Esteban del Rey, Acoma Pueblo
posts.excerpt: This mesa in New Mexico is believed to hold one of the oldest continuously inhabited communities in the US.

posts.title: Doe Shaman Effigy
posts.excerpt: We don’t know what the makers of this figure called her, but we can tell that she is at once human and animal.

posts.title: Mirror Pendant in the Form of a Bat-Human From Grave 5, Sitio Conte
posts.excerpt: This bat-human hybrid preceded the comic version by over a thousand years—move over, Bruce Wayne.

posts.title: Herter Brothers, Mark Hopkins House Side Chair
posts.excerpt: This fancy chair was made for outrageously rich Americans, but its modern style owes much to Japanese design.

posts.title: Mundurukú Headdress: a glimpse of life in the Amazon rainforest
posts.excerpt: Seemingly made completely of feathers, this headdress comes from one of the most biodiverse places on the planet.

posts.title: Olmec mask (offering 20 from the Templo Mayor)
posts.excerpt: This was buried in an offering at an Aztec temple, some 1500 years later and far from where it was made.

posts.title: Coyolxauhqui Monolith
posts.excerpt: The family drama that lead to Coyolxauhqui’s dismemberment represented here has great soap opera potential.

posts.title: Aztec feathered headdress
posts.excerpt: The Mexica were long-distance traders, and Tenochtitlan received luxury goods from distant conquered cities.

posts.title: Kunz Axe (Olmec)
posts.excerpt: In spite its name, this jade figure was a ritual object and never used as an axe.

posts.title: The Sun Stone (or The Calendar Stone) (Aztec)
posts.excerpt: So ubiquitous that it has been used on currency, this unfinished stone records Aztec history and a future prophecy.

posts.title: Charles Willson Peale, The Artist in His Museum
posts.excerpt: What couldn’t Peale do? He is shown as he saw himself: portraitist, naturalist, curator, and Enlightenment thinker.

posts.title: John Singleton Copley, Paul Revere
posts.excerpt: Well known in his own day as a silversmith, Revere is shown in casual attire, with a teapot brimming with meaning.

posts.title: Terms and Issues in Native American Art
posts.excerpt: Too many assumptions persist about Native American arts and cultures—start here to disentangle fact from fiction.

posts.title: About geography and chronological periods in Native American art
posts.excerpt: “Native American” is a broad term encompassing many diverse groups—learn how we organize this section.

posts.title: Teotihuacan
posts.excerpt: The Aztecs knew Teotihuacan as the “city of the gods” and revered it. But who were the people who built it?

posts.title: Jerónimo de Balbás, Altar of the Kings (Altar de los Reyes)
posts.excerpt: This multimedia architectural altarpiece took two decades to complete, and required teams of workers in many media.

posts.title: Kayapó Headdress: a glimpse of life in the Amazon rainforest
posts.excerpt: This object, worn by a child, represents the continuity a way of life that has existed for thousands of years.

posts.title: Fitz Henry Lane, Owl's Head, Penobscot Bay, Maine
posts.excerpt: “Luminism” sounds like a subject at Hogwarts, but it actually describes landscape paintings like this one.

posts.title: Thomas Cole, Expulsion from the Garden of Eden
posts.excerpt: Adam and Eve have just been evicted from Paradise, and the grass was definitely greener on the other side.

posts.title: Winslow Homer, The Life Line
posts.excerpt: Suspended above the sea, the drama of this rescue scene comes from nature, not man.

posts.title: Washington Allston, Elijah in the Desert
posts.excerpt: Can we call a landscape painting “emo”? This brooding, melancholy canvas definitely tempts us to.

posts.title: Thomas Eakins, The Champion Single Sculls (Max Schmitt in a Single Scull)
posts.excerpt: Eakins’ serene river scene celebrates a personal friend as well as an interest in masculine athleticism.

posts.title: Eastman Johnson, A Ride for Liberty -- The Fugitive Slaves
posts.excerpt: Johnson’s moving painting of a family fleeing slavery places the courage of African-Americans center stage.

posts.title: Frederic Edwin Church, Niagara and Heart of the Andes
posts.excerpt: Church was the child star of nineteenth-century landscape painting; these astonishing canvases show us why.

posts.title: Emanuel Leutze, Washington Crossing the Delaware
posts.excerpt: This gigantic canvas is one of the most famous in the history of American art, but it wasn’t made in the USA.

posts.title: George Catlin, The White Cloud, Head Chief of the Iowas
posts.excerpt: This dignified portrait of a Native leader belies the cruel treatment he endured at the time of its painting.

posts.title: Thomas Cole, The Oxbow
posts.excerpt: Not content to merely paint the land, Cole elevated the landscape to approach the status of historical painting.

posts.title: John Vanderlyn, Ariadne Asleep on the Island of Naxos
posts.excerpt: Unusually early for an American artist, Vanderlyn trained in France—but Old World style didn’t sell in America.

posts.title: Thomas Jefferson, Monticello
posts.excerpt: In addition to being a politician, Jefferson was an ardent supporter and practitioner of classical architecture.

posts.title: Gilbert Stuart's Lansdowne Portrait
posts.excerpt: Presidential portraits of George Washington were Stuart’s bread and butter when he returned to his native America.

posts.title: John Singleton Copley, A Boy with a Flying Squirrel (Henry Pelham)
posts.excerpt: Copley was a highly-regarded portrait painter in Boston, but the city was inhospitable to his grander ambitions.

posts.title: John Singleton Copley, The Copley Family
posts.excerpt: Copley introduces both his skill as a painter and his genteel and fashionable family to London society.

posts.title: Benjamin West, The Death of General Wolfe
posts.excerpt: West turned the conventions of history painting on their head by choosing a contemporary subject and dress.

posts.title: The Mesoamerican ballgame and a Classic Veracruz yoke
posts.excerpt: Take me out to the ballgame: hundreds of courts survive for a ritual ballgame that united Mesoamerican society.

posts.title: José María Velasco, The Valley of Mexico from the Santa Isabel Mountain Range
posts.excerpt: Velasco shows us the history of the land, both the natural and the built environments.

posts.title: Carrère & Hastings, The New York Public Library
posts.excerpt: Visitors are welcomed into this monumental temple of knowledge by two lions named Patience and Fortitude.

posts.title: Shrady and Casey, Ulysses S. Grant Memorial
posts.excerpt: Shrady’s sneaky self-portrait within this sculpture took on tragic connotations after the monument claimed his life.

posts.title: Jacob Riis, "Knee-Pants" at Forty-Five Cents a Dozen—A Ludlow Street Sweater’s Shop, from How the Other Half Lives
posts.excerpt: Riis snapped photos of the urban poor during midnight police raids—but only because he cared.

posts.title: Timothy O'Sullivan, Ancient Ruins in the Cañon de Chelle
posts.excerpt: A stunning look at an important Navajo monument reminds us that we’re basically specks in a vast universe.

posts.title: Olmsted and Vaux, Central Park
posts.excerpt: To bring “polite sociability” to the city, designers blended nature’s greatest hits into one ambitious park.

posts.title: John Singer Sargent, The Daughters of Edward Darley Boit
posts.excerpt: Sargent studied the work of Velázquez, and those lessons paid off in this painting of a Bostonian’s daughters.

posts.title: John Singer Sargent, El Jaleo
posts.excerpt: This dramatic dance scene captures a moment in time on an enormous scale.

posts.title: John Singer Sargent, Madame X (Madame Pierre Gautreau)
posts.excerpt: It was all fun and games until the artist painted a woman’s bare shoulder and showed it to a scandalized public.

posts.title: Grafton Tyler Brown, View of the Lower Falls, Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone
posts.excerpt: In order to capture the beauty of America’s national parks, Brown faced the prejudices of the lawless West.

posts.title: Thomas Eakins, The Gross Clinic and The Agnew Clinic
posts.excerpt: Men in suits cut open a leg while their teacher holds a bloody, gloveless hand aloft. Gross indeed.

posts.title: Bernardino de Sahagún and Indigenous collaborators, Florentine Codex
posts.excerpt: Created as a teaching tool, this twelve-volume encyclopedia was made by a Franciscan friar and Nahua collaborators.

posts.title: The Convento of San Nicolás de Tolentino, Actopan, Hidalgo
posts.excerpt: These murals were part of an aggressive campaign to eradicate native beliefs and enforce religious conformity.

posts.title: Frontispiece of the Codex Mendoza
posts.excerpt: Indigenous artists made it. A priest annotated it. But the king in Spain never received it.

posts.title: St. Michael the Archangel in Huejotzingo
posts.excerpt: What does a friary outside of Puebla in Mexico have to do with Jerusalem?

posts.title: Virgin of Guadalupe
posts.excerpt: The Virgin miraculously appeared to a Nahua man in 1531, and has since been the object of intense devotion.

posts.title: All-T’oqapu Tunic
posts.excerpt: Andean cultures had long valued textiles, but they were especially significant and finely-made in the Inka Empire.

posts.title: Machu Picchu
posts.excerpt: The Inka emperor hosted feasts, performed religious ceremonies, and ruled his empire from this remote citadel.

posts.title: Maize cobs
posts.excerpt: A life-size metallic garden at the Qorikancha included these corn cobs, llamas, and other offerings.

posts.title: City of Cuzco
posts.excerpt: It has been argued that Cusco was laid out in the shape of a puma, symbolizing Inka might.

posts.title: Chavín de Huántar
posts.excerpt: The location of Chavín between the desert coast and Amazon made it a key site for transmission of artistic style.

posts.title: The Paracas Textile
posts.excerpt: This nearly 2000-year-old old textile survives thanks to the arid environment of southern Peru where it was buried.

posts.title: The Templo Mayor and the Coyolxauhqui Stone
posts.excerpt: When the Spaniards arrived here, they were amazed by the architecture—but it didn’t stop them from destroying it.

posts.title: Portraits of John and Elizabeth Freake (and their baby)
posts.excerpt: Forget what you think you know about Puritan fashion and get ready to Freake.

posts.title: Transformation masks
posts.excerpt: Wearers can toggle between the faces of animals and mythical beings—all with the tug of a string.

posts.title: Puebloan: Maria Martinez, Black-on-black ceramic vessel
posts.excerpt: Faced with mass production, Maria Martinez continued hand-making pottery as art rather than utilitarian vessels.

posts.title: Feathered war bonnet
posts.excerpt: Coachella style has perpetuated stereotypes—but war bonnets have important cultural and spiritual significance.

posts.title: Eastern Shoshone: Hide Painting of the Sun Dance, attributed to Cotsiogo (Cadzi Cody)
posts.excerpt: Hide painting, a long tradition among Great Basin and Great Plains peoples, was adapted to appeal to tourists.

posts.title: Bandolier Bag
posts.excerpt: These bags imitated the ones European soldiers carried their ammunition in, and were worn during ceremonies.

posts.title: Fourteen portraits of the Inka Kings
posts.excerpt: Genealogical Inka portraits like these were banned by the Spanish who feared they would inspire uprisings.

posts.title: Parish of San Sebastián, Procession of Corpus Christi series
posts.excerpt: Corpus Christi processions celebrate Christ as victor and allude to the triumph of Christianity over paganism.

posts.title: Master of Calamarca, Angel with Arquebus
posts.excerpt: This armed angel was a soldier of the Catholic Church’s ideological army during the Counter Reformation.

posts.title: Cuzco School Artist, Saint Joseph and the Christ Child
posts.excerpt: Joseph plays a bit part in earlier depictions but has an important supporting role in the 16th and 17th centuries.

posts.title: Spaniard and Indian Produce a Mestizo, attributed to Juan Rodríguez Juárez
posts.excerpt: Casta paintings were colonial Mexico’s version of 23andMe—but come from a place of social and racial anxiety.

posts.title: Miguel Cabrera, Portrait of Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz
posts.excerpt: Sor Juana is seated in front of books from her own library, and with implements alluding to her status as a writer.

posts.title: Coatlicue
posts.excerpt: This goddess has clawed feet, and wears a necklace of body parts and the snake-skirt from which she takes her name.

posts.title: Huastec: Life-Death Figure
posts.excerpt: Why is there a ghoulish skeleton on the reverse of this almost life-size sculpture?

posts.title: Mesa Verde
posts.excerpt: Remarkable structures in the American Southwest were home to cliff-dwelling farmers until around 1300.

posts.title: Classic Maya portrait stelae
posts.excerpt: Large stone sculptures was the principal medium for presenting Maya political and religious messages to the public.

posts.title: Tlatilco Figurines
posts.excerpt: Playful figurines, including plump pigs and canine companions, represent scenes of daily life and nature.

posts.title: Fort Ancient Culture: Great Serpent Mound
posts.excerpt: Many interpretations have been proposed for this mound in modern-day Ohio—examine the clues and see what you think.
